Award.AwardTitle: Conference: Social Biomimicry: Insect Societies and Human Design (February 18-20, 2010, Arizona State University, Tempe, AZ)
Award.AbstractNarration: Biomimicry is the practice of imitating nature's forms and processes to more effectively and sustainably meet human design challenges. The conference, Social Biomimicry: Insect Societies and Human Design, will explore how social insects such as ants, bees, and termites can inform human design. Over millions of years, the social insects have evolved tightly integrated societies rivaled only by humans in their scope and sophistication. Individual social insect workers are relatively simple in their behavioral capabilities, but through their collective behavior they have solved many practical problems inherent in large social groups organizing and communicating around common goals. Already, computer models based on ant foraging behavior are being used to route traffic in busy communications networks such as the Internet, and architects are mimicking termite mounds to build passively-cooled buildings that save energy. However, the implementation of social-insect-inspired design has been limited, in part, by lack of communication and coordination across disciplinary and professional boundaries. The conference will address this shortcoming by bringing together biologists - including leaders in the field of social insect biology and complexity theory - with designers, engineers, and businesspeople, with the goal of promoting the exchange of concepts, perspectives, and tools. This activity should (1) enrich biology, by revealing new applications of basic research and stimulating new areas of problem-driven research, and (2) advance the field of biomimicry, which is an important engine for innovation and economic growth. The conference also features a public Social Insect Science EXPO! which will connect researchers at Arizona State University with members of the Phoenix community, including underrepresented students from local K-12 schools. The conference is organized and led by a panel of graduate students from ASU's Social Insect Research Group, and encourages participation by undergraduate and graduate students from the U.S. and abroad. The conference provides a unique opportunity in training future scientists with the leadership skills necessary to organize and run a professional meeting and to communicate and apply their work in an interdisciplinary context. Conference results will be disseminated broadly through peer-reviewed and popular articles and Internet resources.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The field of Biomimicry connects “solutions” found in the natural world with potential applications for human welfare and advancement.  Most research in the field has focused on translating from actual biological structures, such as limbs, or adhesion mechanisms, to tools for human use.  However, the conference, Social Biomimicry, took the concept of biomimicry into the social realm, by discussing how and why aspects of social organization in social insects might connect to solutions for human organizational and management issues.  Because social insect colonies are often extremely large and consist of relatively simple individuals, their organizational structure has lessons for distributed systems control, addressing issues in computer sciences and robotics.  Their biologically evolved architecture and functional design, as examples, passive cooling and carbon dioxide exchange, also connect with human design challenges.  Finally, there are important points of similarity in the organizational objectives and challenges for insect and human societies, particularly in communication and scaling issues. 

The Social Biomimicry conference was held over 3 days and included invited talks by experts on the biology of social insects, as well as mathematical modeling, computer sciences, bioengineering, and biologically inspired design.  In addition to the main presentations, the conference included a series of break-out discussions on the topics of: Social Insects as Models for Biomimetic Design; Bridging Biology and Design; Implementing Social Biomimicry in Human Organizations. These workshops included faculty, graduate students and invited speakers.  A small follow-up workshop, held the next year, focused specifically on the question of how social insect colony organization may provide lessons for business management and leadership.  A special issue on Social Biomimicry, capturing some of these ideas, is currently being planned for the Journal of Bioeconomics.

The conference had a strong student training component.  It was organized and led entirely by graduate students.  The students planned the activities, invited the speakers and managed the conference.  They additionally published a summary article about the conference in the journal, Biology Letters. In association with the main conference, the graduate students organized an outreach activity at the Phoenix Desert Botanical Garden, the Social Insect Science Expo which drew several hundred people to learn about social insects.  The Expo included graduate student volunteers presenting live colonies of leafcutter ants, honeybees, harvester ants, trap-jaw ants, and other social insects. The event provided a valuable opportunity for scientists to connect more directly with the public, and to highlight the value of social insects as inspiration and models for human biomimetic design.
